conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the conductor rod MN as it moves down the vertical rails AB and CD.
The conductor MN moves with a velocity v in a magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane of the rails.
The length of the conductor MN is l, and the height difference between MN and BD is also l.
The induced emf in the loop MNDM is B * v * l.
The resistance of the conductor MN is r * l.
The current I in the loop is B * v / r.
The force on the conductor MN due to the magnetic field is B^2 * v * l / r.
This force acts opposite to the direction of motion of the conductor, so it is a retarding force.
The only other force acting on the conductor is the gravitational force, which is mg (downward).
When the conductor reaches a constant speed, the net force on it is zero.
The retarding force due to the magnetic field is equal to the gravitational force: B^2 * v * l / r = mg.
Solving for v, we get v = mg * r / (B^2 * l).
The velocity of the conductor rod MN when it is moving at a constant speed is mg * r / (B^2 * l).
